The Or HaChama in his commentary on the Zohar wrote some explanation on this matter. The essence of his words is that these two types of wagons allude to two aspects, through which Joseph hinted about the exile and redemption until the end of all generations. That is, Joseph's wagons allude to the time of exile, and wagons are vessels of exile, just as these wagons were used when they went into Egyptian exile. Pharaoh's wagons allude to and serve as a symbolic act regarding the future days of redemption, when the nations of the world will bring the Children of Israel from their lands of exile - "those lost in the land of Assyria and those dispersed in the land of Egypt" - as an offering to Hashem with chariots and mules. This is why the Zohar concludes "when they leave from exile, 'and they shall bring all your brethren as an offering to Hashem,'" for this is alluded to in Pharaoh's wagons - that the nations of the world will bring Israel in their wagons as an offering to Hashem, as explained in the verse.

The Shevivei Nogah wrote that the Zohar disagrees with the opinion in the Midrash which states that those wagons of Pharaoh had idolatrous images engraved on them and Judah stood up and burned them. One can further explain the verse "for you are like Pharaoh" as follows: The holy tribes (Shevatim) prepared through their holy words a prayer and symbolic action for future generations in exile. In every generation, enemies rise up to destroy us, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, saves us from their hands. Through His abundant mercy and kindness, may His name be blessed, He nullifies our enemies' counsel and cancels all harsh decrees against Israel, just as He nullified Pharaoh's decree.

As mentioned in the Gemara (Sotah 12b), Moses was the first to be cast into the Nile. Immediately, the decree was nullified when Pharaoh's astrologers said, "Israel's savior has already been struck," and afterward Moses was saved. Thus, his decree was completely nullified. Similarly, the Holy One, Blessed be He, nullifies the decrees of all who rise against us in every generation.

This is what Yehudah said to Yosef: "You wish to impose a harsh decree upon us from your evil free will. Know that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will nullify your decree, just as He will nullify Pharaoh's decrees in the future." For the holy Patriarchs and tribes saw through their divine inspiration (ruach hakodesh) everything that would happen until the end of generations, except for what was deliberately concealed from Heaven for a specific purpose, such as their inability to recognize Yosef. Similarly, it was concealed from our father Abraham, peace be upon him, during the Akeidah that it wasn't Hashem's will to actually slaughter Yitzchak.

But besides these exceptions, they perceived and saw all future events. Therefore, Yehudah said to Yosef, "for you are like Pharaoh." Just as Pharaoh decrees but doesn't fulfill, as Hashem will nullify his counsel and decree, so too you decree but won't fulfill, and your decree won't stand because the Holy One, Blessed be He, will nullify it.

He further alluded that in every generation, decree-makers would rise against Israel, but Hashem would thwart our enemies' counsel and all would be nullified. This is the meaning of "for you are like Pharaoh" - that people like you and Pharaoh will continue to rise against Israel and issue evil decrees against us, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, will save us from their hands and their decrees will be nullified.

This explains the words of the Midrash: Abba Kohen Bardela said, "Woe to us from the Day of Judgment, woe to us from the Day of Rebuke, etc." Joseph was the youngest of the tribes, and they could not withstand his rebuke, as it is written "and his brothers could not answer him because they were frightened before him." At first glance, what does rebuke have to do with this? Joseph didn't actually rebuke them; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them at that time. So how do we learn about rebuke from here? Also, why is this comparison necessary, and what is the relevance of this analogy?

Following our approach, we can explain that even though there will be great merit for Israel on the Day of Judgment and Rebuke, as the subjugation of exile and the hiding of [God's] face (hester panim) were the causes of our negligence in serving Hashem, and had we merited the revelation of the light of His Divine Presence (Shechinah), we certainly would have been more attached to Him and to the holy Torah. This explains the kal vachomer (a fortiori argument): Joseph didn't rebuke his brothers; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them. Even in the act itself, they had no sin, as explained in the Midrashim that it was to their merit and is remembered forever. Also, it was necessary to fulfill the decree of "Know with certainty." Still, his brothers could not answer him and were frightened before him for the above reason - because they caused the removal of the Divine Presence. How much more so, what will we answer on the Day of Judgment?

This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. matched_passages.passage: ואפ"ל בזה מאמר הכתוב כו עיניכם הרואות וגו' כי פו המדבר אליכם, ודרשו חז"ל כפו כן לבי, כי הנה בפסוק שלפניו כתוב וכלכלתו אתך שם כו עוד חמש שנים רעב פן תורש אתה וביתך וכל אשר לך, ולכאורה הרי לא נתקיים הבטחתו מה שנדר לזונם ולכלכלם עוד חמש שנים, שהרי אמרז"ל משבא יעקב אבינו למצרים נפסק הרעב מיד בזכותו ויתכן שהשיג יוסף ברוה"ק שעתיד הרעב להתבטל עצו יע"א, כי אמרו רז"ל בפדר"א שרוח הקודש הנהיגתו מנעוריו ועד יום מותו, א"כ מדוע אמר וכלכלתי אתך וגו' כו עוד חמש שנים הרעב ולא נתקיים נדרו, אולם הרי קיי"ל דאין סומכין על הנס, ע"כ יוסף הצדיק השתתף בצערם וקיבל על עצמו בכל לבו ונפשו לזונם ולכלכלם עוד חמש שנים, ובזה כבר קיבל השכר על כל החמש שנים אף שנפסק הרעב אח"כ, כמבואר בדברי הספרי הנ"ל שמגיע שכר על האמירה אף שלא הספיק ליתן, וכדי שלא יקשה לאחיו עליו. האיך הותר לו לנדור בכהאי גוונא והלא אסור לנדור אלא באומר הרי זו, אמנם ביררנו לעיל דבמחשבתו רצויה מותר, ע"כ הסמיך לומר כי עיניכם הרואות כו פו המדבר אליכם, ודרשו רז"ל כפי כן לבי. היינו שמחשבתי וכוונתי רצויה, ובכהאי גוונא מצוה לנדור ומקבל שכר על האמירה כמעשה, והנה ישנם כאלו שחושבים כי בלאו הכי הוא מעשה נסים, לקיים ולהחזיק מוסד גדול בלי עין הרע בהוצאות גדולות ע"י מתו מעט ומספר מצומצם של יר"א, וע"כ סומך הוא על הנס וחושב שאינו צריך ליקח חבל ויבוא הנס מ"מ, אבל אינו כן כי אין סומכין על הנס. ורק בכח הזה שבנ"י נותנים במסירות ובמחשבה רצויה אנו מתקיימים למעלה מדרך הטבע.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

One can explain the verse "Your eyes see... for it is my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart." In the previous verse it states "I will sustain you there... for there are yet five years of famine, lest you come to poverty, you, and your household, and all that you have." However, seemingly Yosef's promise to feed and sustain them for five more years wasn't fulfilled, as Chazal say that when Yaakov Avinu came to Egypt, the famine immediately ceased in his merit.

It's possible that Yosef knew through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) that the famine would end with Yaakov's arrival, as Chazal say in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that Ruach HaKodesh guided him from his youth until his death. If so, why did he say "I will sustain you... for five more years of famine" when his vow wasn't fulfilled?

However, we have a principle that one shouldn't rely on miracles. Therefore, Yosef HaTzaddik empathized with their suffering and took upon himself wholeheartedly to feed and sustain them for five years. For this, he already received reward for all five years even though the famine ended earlier, as explained in the aforementioned Sifri that one receives reward for the declaration even if unable to complete the action.

So his brothers wouldn't question how he was permitted to make such a vow, since it's forbidden to make vows except by saying "Harei Zu" (behold this is), we explained earlier that it's permitted with proper intention. Therefore, he immediately said "Your eyes see... my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart" - meaning his thoughts and intentions were proper, and in such a case it's a mitzvah to make a vow and one receives reward for the declaration as if for the action.

There are those who think that maintaining a large institution with great expenses through limited means and a small number of God-fearing supporters is anyway miraculous, and therefore rely on miracles, thinking they don't need to take action as the miracle will come regardless. But this isn't correct, as we don't rely on miracles. Only through the power of Jews giving with self-sacrifice and proper intention can we exist beyond natural means.
